areas.selectAreas: Select what areas you want to focus on
areas.confirmAddSupplements: Do you want to add supplements for this area?

selectArea.description: Different tips and supplements can help you achieve your health goals. Select one for more information

goalDetails.lockedTipInfo: This is a more advanced tip. Explore the basics for best results.
goalDetails.basicTipInfo: This is a basic tip that helps you build a solid foundation.
goalDetails.unlockedTipInfo: This is an in-depth tip. Builds on the foundation.
goalDetails.analyzeHint: You can analyze once the time period is over.
goalDetails.analysisMatch: ‚úÖ The supplement matches the goal with {{confidence}}% certainty.
goalDetails.analysisError: Something went wrong during the analysis. Please try again.
goalDetails.permissionDenied: Camera access is required to take a photo.

cardioOverview.title: Cardiovascular Health
cardioOverview.description: Heart, blood vessels, and overall cardiovascular function

vo2Max.title: VO‚ÇÇ Max
vo2Max.description: VO‚ÇÇ max measures the maximum amount of oxygen your body can use during intense exercise. It's the gold standard for cardiovascular fitness. Higher values indicate better endurance capacity.

restingHeartRate.title: Resting Heart Rate
restingHeartRate.description: Lower resting heart rate typically indicates better cardiovascular fitness. Athletes often have resting heart rates below 60 bpm. Monitor trends over time. A sudden increase may signal overtraining, illness, or stress.

trainingLoad.title: Training Load
trainingLoad.description: Training Load tracks the cumulative intensity and volume of your workouts over 7 days. Optimal load means you're training effectively without overtraining. Too high = risk of injury/burnout. Too low = insufficient stimulus for adaptation.

recoveryTime.title: Recovery Time
recoveryTime.description: Time needed before your body is ready for another hard training session. Based on HRV, sleep quality, and body battery. Respecting recovery prevents injury and improves performance. Training hard when recovery is incomplete leads to diminished returns.

fitnessAge.title: Fitness Age
fitnessAge.description: Based on your VO‚ÇÇ max, resting heart rate, and other factors. A lower fitness age indicates superior cardiovascular health. Regular aerobic training can reduce your fitness age by 10-20 years compared to sedentary peers.

digestiveOverview.title: Digestive Health
digestiveOverview.description: Gut function, microbiome, and digestive wellness

energyOverview.title: Energy Systems
energyOverview.description: Mitochondrial function and cellular energy production

cellularEnergyReserves.title: Cellular Energy Reserves
cellularEnergyReserves.explainer: Body Battery tracks your body's energy reserves by monitoring stress, activity, and recovery. It reflects your mitochondrial ATP production capacity.

energyProductionMetrics.title: Energy Production Metrics
energyProductionMetrics.explainer: VO‚ÇÇ max indicates mitochondrial density and oxidative capacity. Higher values = more efficient ATP production from oxygen.

energyBalance.title: Energy Balance
energyBalance.explainer: Deep sleep is when mitochondrial repair and autophagy (cellular cleanup) occur. Chronic stress increases cortisol, which impairs mitochondrial function.

powerhouses.title: The Powerhouses of Your Cells
powerhouses.description: Mitochondria are organelles that produce ATP (adenosine triphosphate), the energy currency of all cells. Each cell contains hundreds to thousands of mitochondria. They convert nutrients and oxygen into ~90% of your body's energy.

atpProduction.title: ATP Production
atpProduction.description: Through oxidative phosphorylation, mitochondria produce 30-32 ATP molecules per glucose molecule (vs only 2 ATP from glycolysis). This process requires oxygen, which is why VO‚ÇÇ max correlates with energy capacity.

mitochondrialBiogenesis.title: Mitochondrial Biogenesis
mitochondrialBiogenesis.description: Exercise (especially Zone 2 cardio) triggers PGC-1Œ± activation, which increases mitochondrial density. More mitochondria = more energy production capacity. This is why trained athletes have higher VO‚ÇÇ max.

oxidativeStress.title: Oxidative Stress
oxidativeStress.description: Mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) as byproducts of ATP production. Excessive ROS causes oxidative damage to mitochondrial DNA. Antioxidants (Vitamin C, E, CoQ10, glutathione) help neutralize ROS and protect mitochondrial function.

nadDecline.title: NAD+ and Energy Decline
nadDecline.description: NAD+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) is essential for mitochondrial function. NAD+ levels decline ~50% between ages 20-80, reducing ATP production efficiency. NAD+ precursors (NR, NMN) and sirtuins activators may support mitochondrial health.

mitophagy.title: Mitophagy & Cellular Cleanup
mitophagy.description: Mitophagy is the selective autophagy of damaged mitochondria. Occurs during fasting and deep sleep. Regular mitophagy prevents accumulation of dysfunctional mitochondria that produce excess ROS and less ATP.

todaysActivity.title: Today's activity
todaysActivity.explainer: Regular movement throughout the day maintains mitochondrial health. Even light activity (walking) stimulates ATP production and reduces oxidative stress.

immuneOverview.title: Immune System
immuneOverview.description: Defense against pathogens and immune regulation

sleep.title: Sleep
sleep.description: Adequate sleep is crucial for immune function. During sleep, the body produces cytokines that help fight infection and inflammation.

stress.title: Stress & Body Battery
stress.description: Chronic stress suppresses immune function. Body Battery reflects your energy reserves and recovery status.

hrv.title: HRV (Heart Rate Variability)
hrv.description: Higher HRV indicates better recovery and resilience. Low HRV may signal stress, fatigue, or illness.

restingHeartRate.title: Resting Heart Rate
restingHeartRate.description: An elevated resting heart rate can be an early sign of illness, inflammation, or inadequate recovery.

nervousSystemOverview.title: Nervous System
nervousSystemOverview.description: Autonomic nervous system balance and recovery metrics

ansBalance.title: Sympathetic vs Parasympathetic
ansBalance.parasympathetic: Your nervous system is currently in a parasympathetic-dominant state, indicating good recovery and relaxation.
ansBalance.balanced: Your nervous system shows balanced activity between sympathetic and parasympathetic, suggesting you are managing stress well and have good recovery capacity.
ansBalance.sympathetic: Your nervous system is currently in a sympathetic-dominant state, which may indicate stress or inadequate recovery. Consider prioritizing rest, deep breathing, or relaxing activities.

hrv.title: HRV (Heart Rate Variability)
hrv.description: HRV measures the variation in time between heartbeats. Higher HRV indicates better autonomic nervous system function, resilience, and recovery capacity. It's influenced by stress, sleep, fitness, and overall health.

stressScore.title: Stress Score
stressScore.description: Based on HRV, activity, and sleep data. Lower scores (0-25) indicate low stress, while higher scores (75-100) show significant sympathetic nervous system activation. Chronic high stress can lead to burnout and health issues.

bodyBattery.title: Body Battery
bodyBattery.description: Tracks your body's energy reserves by monitoring stress, activity, and recovery. It reflects your autonomic nervous system balance and recovery status.

ansBalance.title: ANS Balance
ansBalance.description: The balance between sympathetic (stress response) and parasympathetic (recovery response) activity. Predominant parasympathetic activity indicates good recovery, while predominant sympathetic activity may signal stress or inadequate recovery.

mindOverview.title: Mind & Cognition
mindOverview.description: Cognitive function, mental performance, and brain health

focus.title: Focus & Mental Clarity
focus.description: High stress and low energy (body battery) impair prefrontal cortex function, leading to reduced focus, mental clarity, and decision-making ability.

stress.title: Stress & Body Battery
stress.description: Chronic stress impairs cognitive function and mental performance. Body Battery reflects your energy reserves and recovery status, which are crucial for optimal brain function.

mood.title: Mood & Emotional Regulation
mood.description: Chronic stress and poor recovery can lead to mood disturbances, anxiety, and depression. Prioritizing recovery and stress management supports emotional well-being.

sleepQuality.title: Sleep Quality
sleepQuality.description: Poor sleep quality negatively impacts memory, attention, and executive function. Prioritizing good sleep is essential for maintaining cognitive health.

steps.title: üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Steps & Brain Health
steps.description: Physical activity and daily steps increase blood flow to the brain, improving memory and concentration while reducing stress and risk of mental health issues.

bdnf.title: üß¨ BDNF and Brain Development
bdnf.description: BDNF (Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor) is a protein that plays a crucial role in brain plasticity, learning, and memory. Physical activity, especially intense exercise, increases BDNF levels, contributing to better cognitive function and protection against mental health issues.

sleepStages.title: Sleep stages
sleepStages.explainer: Deep sleep is crucial for physical recovery and immune function. REM sleep supports memory consolidation and emotional regulation.

stages.title: Stages
stages.description: Sleep cycles through 4 stages: Light (N1, N2), Deep (N3), and REM. Each stage has unique benefits. Adults need 7-9 hours with balanced stage distribution for optimal recovery.

deepSleep.title: Deep Sleep
deepSleep.description: Deep sleep (slow-wave sleep) is when your body repairs tissues, builds muscle, strengthens immune system, and consolidates memories. Growth hormone peaks during this stage. Aim for 15-25% of total sleep time.

remSleep.title: REM Sleep
remSleep.description: REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep processes emotions, consolidates learning, and supports creativity. Most vivid dreams occur here. REM should be 20-25% of total sleep and increases in later cycles.

circadianRhythm.title: Circadian Rhythm
circadianRhythm.description: Your internal 24-hour clock regulates sleep-wake cycles, hormone release, and body temperature. Consistent sleep/wake times strengthen circadian rhythm and improve sleep quality.

strengthOverview.title: Strength & Muscle Health
strengthOverview.description: Muscle function, strength training, and recovery

recoveryFactors.title: Recovery factors
recoveryFactors.explainer: Sleep and HRV are primary drivers of muscle recovery and protein synthesis. Deep sleep stages trigger growth hormone release for muscle repair. Respecting recovery prevents injury and promotes strength gains. Training hard when recovery is incomplete leads to diminished returns and increased injury risk.

trainingReadiness.title: Training Readiness
trainingReadiness.description: Combines HRV, sleep quality, recovery time, and recent training load to predict your body's preparedness for high-intensity strength training. Scores above 75 indicate optimal conditions for progressive overload.

trainingLoad.title: Training Load
trainingLoad.description: Quantifies training stress from the past 7 days. Anaerobic load specifically measures high-intensity work (heavy lifting, HIIT). Maintaining load within your optimal range prevents overtraining while ensuring progression.

recoveryTime.title: Recovery Time
recoveryTime.description: Estimated hours until full muscular and CNS recovery. Heavy compound lifts (squats, deadlifts) require 48-72h for complete recovery. Training the same muscle groups before recovery is complete impairs adaptation.

sleepMuscleGrowth.title: Sleep & Muscle Growth
sleepMuscleGrowth.description: 80% of growth hormone is released during deep sleep. Sleep deprivation reduces protein synthesis by ~20% and increases cortisol (catabolic). Aim for 7-9 hours with sleep quality above 80% for optimal hypertrophy.

genesList.title: Genes & DNA
genesList.noGenes: No genes linked to this area yet.
genesList.genesAffectHealth: Multiple genes influence your health and function in this area. Understanding your genetic predispositions can help you tailor your health plan to optimize results.
genesList.explainer: Genetic testing can provide insights into your profile, but lifestyle always has the biggest impact!

chat.welcomeMessage: Hi! I'm your personal health coach ‚Äì specialized in biohacking and supplements. Ask me about daily routines or optimizing your health. üí™üåø
chat.introPrompt: I just added a new health goal ({{goal}}). It includes these supplements: {{supplements}}. Do you have any tips or warnings?
chat.askToAddSupplements: Do you want me to add these supplements to your plan? Reply 'yes' or 'no'.

onboarding.whatSupplementDoYouTakeAlready: What supplements do you take already?

dashboard.xpInfo: XP measures your knowledge level in different health categories. By exploring tips, you increase your XP and unlock more advanced recommendations.
